div1.head: Analysis
div1.p: In part because of the continuing influence of minstrelsy on theater in the United States, revisionary depictions of Africa in African American drama lagged somewhat behind those in American Black fiction. An early musical comedy set in Africa starring the famous team of George Walker and Bert Williams (credited with popularizing the cakewalk), In Dahomey (1902) had lyrics by Paul Laurence Dunbar, book by Jesse A. Shipp, and music by Will Marion Cook. A parody of back-to-Africa movements, the story concerns two detectives, Shylock Homestead (Williams) and Rareback Pinkerton (Walker), hired by the Dahomey Colonization Society to find a missing treasure. According to one description of the play, all the characters "end up in Dahomey where they are nearly executed. They decide there's no place like home." The musical contained songs with lyrics such as "We are the loyal subjects of King Eat-Em-All,/The ruler over all our states both great and small" and "We'd sell big Georgia possums some watermelons too/To git the coin for the other things we'd like to do." Walker and Williams also appeared in and helped write the book for another musical set in Africa, Shipp and Alex Rogers's Abyssinia (1906).
